channel.title: First computer
channel.description:
Ok, this is my first time building a computer lol, and I'm only doing it so I can play FFXIV.
I have to meet these reqs: [img]http://i.imgur.com/qtNhu.png[/img]
And this is the build I currently have: [img]http://i.imgur.com/mwYNp.png[/img]
Can you guys see anyway I could shave off some of the $$ ? (And also, can you tell if everything will work together rofl, I don't want my first project to be a complete dud)

item.title: First computer
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

for a start your mobo only supports sata ii(retronamed to sata 3gb/s) while your harddrive is sata iii(marketing fags call this sata 6gb/s), but also scrap both since they’re both expensive, and while you’re at it scrap the ram

now here’s what you want to do, find the cheapest mobo that supports your cpu with at least 2 but preferably 4 sata ii connectors, buy the cheapest 4gb 1033 or whatever ram you can that is supported by the mobo, find a cheap harddrive or use this one and maybe find a cheaper psu and you’re good to go

ps I’d avoid hitachi drives like the plague, my 2tb hitachi drive sounds like its dying every time I do anything intensive on it(copying semilarge files, extracting), has a bad sector and it’s been powered on for 285 days, compared to my 500gb wd drive that smart calls healthy with 1.6 years power on time.

Read full topic

item.title: First computer
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:5, topic:382742”]never had problems with WD. never heard of anyone having problems with WD other than mitb. but i have heard of people having problems with hitachi… but its a horrible way to determine which ones better[/quote]That basically. I have a WD now and there have been no problems for the 4 years i’ve had it. I’ve had shitloads of problems with Maxtor Diamondmax 9-series (but i’m pretty sure most people have as a ton of them had a manufacturing defect). Doesn’t mean i discourage anyone from buying the new ones though.

PS: 8GB ram is worth it if you run a modern operating system with a decent cache system.

Read full topic

item.title: First computer
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

never had problems with WD. never heard of anyone having problems with WD other than mitb. but i have heard of people having problems with hitachi… but its a horrible way to determine which ones better

Read full topic

item.title: First computer
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

That much RAM is a little much, it’s up to you though. (you are going to use a 64-bit OS right? Otherwise there is no use to getting more than 3gb or so)

As to the hard drive, I just bought one of these:

newegg.com

Hitachi GST Deskstar 5K3000 HDS5C3020ALA632 (0F12117) 2TB 32MB Cache...

Buy Hitachi GST Deskstar 5K3000 HDS5C3020ALA632 (0F12117) 2TB 32MB Cache SATA 6.0Gb/s 3.5" Internal Hard Drive Bare Drive with fast shipping and top-rated customer service. Newegg shopping upgraded ™

It’s the same speed, 2TB instead of 1TB, $10 cheaper, and probably a better company. I hate Western Digital, I’ve had nothing but bad experience with them. I’ve only had this drive for a few days, but it can’t be worse than WD.

Read full topic

item.title: First computer
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“headlights, post:2, topic:382742”]8GB of RAM is unnecessary. 4GB is more than enough.

You could get away with using a less-powerful processor. A dual-core CPU (Core i3, perhaps) would suffice.

You could buy a cheaper power supply (don’t buy from a cheap brand, though!). A 550W PSU would do, which you can get from Corsair.[/quote]
you wont save much by switching to a less powerful cpu though

Read full topic

item.title: First computer
item.dc:creator: @headlights headlights
item.description:
@headlights wrote:

8GB of RAM is unnecessary. 4GB is more than enough.

You could get away with using a less-powerful processor. A dual-core CPU (Core i3, perhaps) would suffice.

You could buy a cheaper power supply (don’t buy from a cheap brand, though!). A 550W PSU would do, which you can get from Corsair.

Read full topic
